Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2007 11:22AM GrandmaWolf wrote: nosurrender 4 Oct 2005 07:34 AM I was just crusing thru some of these postings when i came across this one from almost 2years ago.  I recall these same feelings with my first diagnosis 8 years ago.  Yep, like you NoSurrender, I made it thorough.  Now, with my second primary I face chemo again. You made me smile with reassurances once again. thanks grandma Wolf
Posts.Title: 2005 ROCK-TOBER CHEMO GIRLS sherryhaire Curlylocks

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2007 06:28PM - edited Nov 15, 2007 06:30PM by GrandmaWolf Bimmer... contact the Hospice in your area. They can be of immense help even at home.  I have been the wife of someone with a different type of cancer... going down the same pain highway.  They can help with pain like hospitals can't.  A dear friend with breast cancer was eased with Hospice assistance.  Now, for the third time, I myself have a breast cancer diagnosis.  If the time comes where Pain is the PRIMARY issue to quality of life, they are on the top of my list. Someone who knows the ache in your soul. GrandmaWolf
Posts.Title: Very advanced B.C. III: Battling the beast Bimmer JoyRebecca

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2007 06:47PM - edited Nov 23, 2007 06:51PM by GrandmaWolf Bimmer, While I am a breast cancer person myself, facing chemo and surgery , I am not coming from there, but from the caretaker's positon of a loved one, that you are in .  I have been in a similar position as care giver to my husband in the last stages of Non-Hodgskins Lymphoma.  I say similar because of your reference to the pain control measures. In my area there is a WONDERFUl hospice service.  A person can check in and out as needed, to stablize the pain, or be an inhouse resident,  able to have pet's, friends, and more importantly, "expert" round the clock care over and above what is available at a hospital.  If Diane's doctors indicated what I am assuming is true, Hospice would give Diane the constant, comfortable care 24hrs, while you work...and come back to give back up care.  It would be a win-win, for the financial situation, and Dianes care, & comfort. I don't know if your area has what I am refering to, but it is worth investigating. If not appropriate now, bookmark it for any future possible resource. It is a hard hard place you both are in.  Diane is fortunate to have you in her corner. with intense empathy Grandma Wolf  aka Dakota
Posts.Title: Something else we all have to deal with. Bimmer AliceJean

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2007 08:53PM - edited Dec 4, 2007 08:55PM by GrandmaWolf KatoMato...  Oh... thank you for sharing your experience on TC.  Eight years after being on the A/C combination, I am facing my first TC treatment the day after tomorrow.  I have read the "horror stories", which my dr's did not confirm...nor did your experience.  I didn't do too badly on the A/C, and hope to follow in your TC footsteps. Your posting was the best thing I could have read tonight. thank you... Grandma Wolf..aka Dakota
Posts.Title: TC Chemo coming up-please share with me mikim auntienance

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2007 06:50PM GrandmaWolf wrote: ChemoMom, aka Angie You should be proud of yourself to deal with what is... head on. You provide reassurance for those of us facing bilateral in the near future.  I too am planning, to skip reconstruction & all it's issues. I have in front of me a catalog from the ACS, called "TLC".  It has all sorts of products, from wigs, bras and breast forms at a reasonable price.  I am considering contacting my local chapter to see if they can help me out with these issues. I do like the bras I see in the catalog better than some of the websites I have visited. Is there a local chapter near you that you could get advice from other women in your area? Keep us posted on your progress...and thank you for your input. Grandma Wolf  aka Dakota
Posts.Title: Can I go form-free after bilateral mastectomy? chemomom Erica

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2008 11:21AM - edited Jun 5, 2008 11:24AM by GrandmaWolf BustersMom, I am 3 weeks post bilateral mastectomy.  I had all my shopping, cleaning and laundry done before surgery.  Stayed overnight at the hospital.  Was so glad to get home, so I could sleep and rest.  I was alone all day & night. My daughter would call, and stop over once a day to see what I needed.  I had a visiting nurse stop twice to check the dressing and drains. I was able to shower, and do the usual daily type things, there was no rush to do anything.  Had some good books, and took a lot of naps for the first week.  Discomfort was controlled with a tylenol...no real pain.  Sensitive skin, and chest tightness continue, but I am back to work.  I can only speak for myself, but reading a lot of these postings, I know I am not unique.  Just get as much info as you can,,, ask the Dr, and nurses what to expect, and have help nearby "in case" you need it.  I found the following YouTube video discussion on drains.  Just copy and paste the link into the address field of your browser if it doesn't work by clicking on it. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vvMgjBtGsOc Keep us posted, and best of luck Dakota
Posts.Title: How long will I need FT help at home after surgery? BustersMom Nice_Nichols

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2007 10:24AM GrandmaWolf wrote: Natalie, I just had my first of 4 taxotere, and cytoxan tx's...with the neulesta shot.  While the taxotere causes bone aches and pains, so does the neulesta.  Double whammy. My sternum is killing me...and I am told the neulesta itself can cause bone pain.  Almost nine years ago i was on the "big bad" Adriamycin, and Cytoxan...no neulesta or anything else.  it was ruff, but i didn't have such an immediate slap down. It took at least until the 2nd treatment, and then after a couple of days I could dig out.  The aches and fatique of this, almost a week after the first treatment, are not encouraging to say the least. If anyone else out there has experience with this combination, I am sure Natalie and I would like to hear about it. Dakota
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: May 28, 2008 08:01PM GrandmaWolf wrote: Oh, Swimangel72, I am sorry you went through all the hoops that usually promise the best ending to find that not only did it not, but it added misery to your already awful experience of breast cancer.  Please don't feel obilqued to answer, for it is none of my business, but why on earth is the Diep foob so much larger, and more combersome than the original you?  Don't you think it may just take time to adjust?  Your mention of the no feeling issue is the main reason I chose not to reconstruct.  The visuals would be for others benefit, not mine.  I am hoping that time resolves all these problems for you, and you end up happy with the results of your efforts. Dakota
Posts.Title: reconstruction or not ????? vivianu spar2

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2011 11:06AM GrandmaWolf wrote: Marlee,  I am suprised no one has mentioned the Breast Free website.  It is very informative with pictures and personal stories.   As I was 64 three years ago when I had my bilateral, I figured the pain and surgery time for reconstruction just wasn't worth it.  Especially when the reconstructed implants don't have anymore feeling than my prothesis, which I can change to suit my needs.  Face it nothing would replace my real breasts, and while there are times I still miss them, I know I made the right decision, and haven't looked back The numbness, and chest tightness of bilateral are issues with or without reconstruction.  The band around my chest still feels like I always have a bra on, but it is not painful, and diminishes bit by bit over time.  Hope this helps with your decision. Dakota, aka Grandma Wolf
Posts.Title: No reconstruction- Happy w/your decision? marlee1 quietpools

Posts.Content: May 27, 2008 11:14PM GrandmaWolf wrote: Vivianu, You asked to hear from those who opt'd NOT to have reconstruction. I qualify to answer.  Like yourself, I am 65, and not in a relationship. I had a bilateral 2 1/2 weeks ago.   I thought it would be harder than it is looking down at a flat chest.  I know I can reconstruct at any time in the future, but now on this side of the surgery I have to wonder why I would go through all of that trouble for something that would look good in clothes, but have no feeling?  I don't look "bad" in clothes, even flat, and with decent prothesis, no one would know if they were reconstructs, or add ons.   As for the possibility of meeting someone in the future, I don't think if the person were the type to let boobs interfer with an otherwise good relationship, he would be the person for me.  Ahem, I do have "other" skills. Yes, there maybe times I will miss them, they were good looking boobs for a woman my age... but hey those puppies were trying to kill me as they were drooping toward the floor.  I really like the idea of tattos to fill in the "blank" slate.  I have seen some very interesting ones, but will need to wait at least a year. Here's hoping you come to a comfortable decison that suits what feels best for you. Dakota
Posts.Title: reconstruction or not ????? vivianu spar2

Posts.Content: May 29, 2008 04:41AM - edited May 29, 2008 04:51AM by GrandmaWolf Swimangle72 I think each and everyone of us can agree with your very last statement. However, from what you just described, it may be just a matter of time if you can just hold out.  My younger sister went thru reconstruction a year after her surgery.  It did take almost about a year of discomfort, etc, etc.  Her ps was totally upfront and honest with her about the process, and the results.  That was over 20 years ago, and she has been glad she did it ever since.   Pehaps a couple more years down the line, you will look back and think all of this is worth it too.  In the meantime, why don't you address your concerns directly to the ps?  IE... mention your surgeon & LE aren't entirely convinced all of this is swelling.  How long can you "reasonably" expect swelling to last? Ask directly why he created the size he did after you explained you did not want the otherside augmented.  See if the explainations to yourself are correct.  I think you have every right to know, and "understand" what is going on.  If you don't, it is his duty to inform you. Hang in there ....  dakota
Posts.Title: reconstruction or not ????? vivianu spar2

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2007 07:01PM GrandmaWolf wrote: ChemoMom... You are reasurance to a woman almost twice your age.  Having had 3 distinct primaries in 8 years, I am sneaking up on the idea of a  bilateral after chemo.  If I do, I cannot see any purpose in going thru all the added trauma of replacing the irreplacable (at least for me). There is a part of me that hangs back with trepidation...but the other half of me says, just "get on with it" and go on living a meaningful life.  You confirm that is possible. thanks GrandmaWolf...aka Dakota
